sen.j: 初代 忠吉は、肥前新刀鍛冶。
sen.e: Chukichi the first was a swordsmith of Hizen Shinto (modern sword).

sen.j: 新刀最上作最上大業物 山城国埋忠明寿門人。
sen.e: He was a disciple of Myoju UMETADA of Yamashiro Province, who was Shinto Mogamisaku, Mogami Oowazamono (highest rating of swordsmith).

sen.j: 制作の時期により、五字忠銘、秀岸銘、住人銘、改銘後の忠広銘に分かれる。
sen.e: Depending on the period of production, his swords are classified into Gojitada-mei, Shugan-mei, Junin-mei, and Tadahiro-mei after change of his signature (inscription).

sen.j: 初期は「五字忠銘」といって「肥前国忠吉」の銘がほとんどのようである。
sen.e: His early swords are called 'Gojitada-mei' and most of them are believed to be signed by 'Hizen no kuni (Hizen Province) Chukichi'.
His early swords are called 'Gojitada-mei' and most of them are believed to be signed as 'Hizen no kuni (Hizen Province) Chukichi'.
sen.cmt: 「肥前国忠吉」の銘の訳で、「signed by」とありますが、「signed as」だとおもいます。
sen.e: His early swords are called 'Gojitada-mei' and most of them are believed to be signed as 'Hizen no kuni (Hizen Province) Chukichi'.

sen.j: 秀岸というのは僧侶らしく、この人の書く字を真似て切った癖のある切銘のことを言う。
sen.e: Shugan seems to be a Buddhist monk and Shugan-mei refers to Chukichi's signature with mannerisms inscribed on a sword by imitating the letters written by this monk.

The source of the 'Shugan-mei' seems to be a Buddhist monk, and Shugan-mei refers to the swords with a specific mannerism of Chukichi with his signature inscribed on a sword by imitating the letters written by this monk.
sen.cmt: 多少訳文の意味が通じづらいと感じましたので修正しました。
sen.e: The source of the 'Shugan-mei' seems to be a Buddhist monk, and Shugan-mei refers to the swords with a specific mannerism of Chukichi with his signature inscribed on a sword by imitating the letters written by this monk.

sen.j: 秀岸銘をやめてのち、「肥前国住人忠吉作」などと切る住人銘になる。
sen.e: After he stopped using Shugan-mei, he used Junin-mei, inscribing 'Hizen no kuni Junin Chukichi saku' (made by Chukichi living in Hizen Province) and so on.
After he stopped using Shugan-mei, he used Junin-mei, inscribing 'Hizen no kuni Junin Chukichi saku' (made by Chukichi living in Hizen Province).
sen.cmt: 「and so on」は不要ですので削除しました。
sen.e: After he stopped using Shugan-mei, he used Junin-mei, inscribing 'Hizen no kuni Junin Chukichi saku' (made by Chukichi living in Hizen Province).

sen.j: 晩年は武蔵大掾を受領し名を「忠広」と改め「武蔵大掾藤原忠広」と切る。
sen.e: In his later years, he received the title of Musashi Daijo and changed his name to 'Tadahiro' and inscribed 'Musashi Daijo Fujiwara Tadahiro' on a sword.
In his later years, he started inscribing as 'Musashi Daijo Fujiwara Tadahiro' on his swords after he received the title of Musashi Daijo and changed his name to 'Tadahiro'.
sen.cmt: 語順を変え、andの多用を避けました。
sen.e: In his later years, he started inscribing as 'Musashi Daijo Fujiwara Tadahiro' on his swords after he received the title of Musashi Daijo and changed his name to 'Tadahiro'.

sen.j: 重要美術品の刀、脇差しがある。
sen.e: There are swords and wakizashi (short swords) that are important arts.
Some of his swords and wakizashi (short swords) are designated as Tangible Cultural Properties of Japan.
sen.cmt: 「重要美術品」は訳のように一般的な意味ではなく、ここでは「重要文化財」などと同等の意味を持つ日本の特定有形文化財を指します。そのように訂正しました。
sen.e: Some of his swords and wakizashi (short swords) are designated as Tangible Cultural Properties of Japan.

sen.j: 息子の近江大掾忠広以下、幕末まで一貫して続く肥前刀の開祖といえよう。
sen.e: It can be said that he was the originator of Hizen-to (the sword of Hizen Province) which was consistently followed by his son Omi Daijo Tadahiro and his descendants until the end of Edo period.

It is considered that he was the originator of Hizen-to (the sword of Hizen Province) whose technique was successively inherited by his son Omi Daijo Tadahiro and his descendants until the end of Edo period.
sen.cmt: 「ーといえよう」を直訳していますので修正しました。「一貫して続く」を「consistently followed」としていますが、直訳的で本意と意味が多少異なると思います。
sen.e: It is considered that he was the originator of Hizen-to (the sword of Hizen Province) whose technique was successively inherited by his son Omi Daijo Tadahiro and his descendants until the end of Edo period.
